dc:title: Size-selective sex-allocation and host feeding in a parasitoid-host model
dc:creator: Murdoch W.
dc:description: Hymenopterous parasitoids frequently exhibit size-selective sex-allocation, laying predominantly male eggs in smaller host individuals and female eggs in larger hosts, and size-selective host-feeding, ie feeding on and killing, but not parasitizing, smaller host individuals. Size-selective sex-allocation and host-feeding (SSH) is analysed using a parasitoid-host model that recognizes overlapping generations, an invulnerable adult host stage, a young immature stage, an old immature host stage, and only the female parasitoid. Young immature hosts are assumed to be attacked by the parasitoids, die as a consequence, but do not contribute to the juvenile female parasitoid population; each attack on an old immature host produces a juvenile female parasitoid. SSH leads to delayed pseudo-density-dependence in recruitment to the parasitoid population because the current attack rate on young immatures, which is a function of parasitoid density, influences the future number of old immatures and hence the future per head rate of recruitment of searching parasitoids. SSH is potentially stabilizing because it tends to suppress the inherent long-period host-parasitoid cycles. This stabilizing propensity is enhanced when the adult host stage lasts about as long as or longer than the entire immature host stage is not too long-lived or the attack rate on it is not too high. SSH can also destabilize the model by creating a region of instability in which cycles occur with a period related to the total length of the host immature stages. These shorter-period cycles are promoted by the same features that tend to suppress the underlying parasitoid-host cycles. -from Authors

dc:title: Compartments and predation in an estuarine food web
dc:creator: Raffaelli D.
dc:description: The proposition that strong functional predator-prey links are associated with compartments in food webs is examined for the Ythan Estuary, Scotland. There was evidence for significant compartmentation in several previously published real webs, but there was no evidence of compartments in the Ythan web. Manipulative field experiments on the range of avian, fish and invertebrate predators provided no evidence for strong functional interactions in the Ythan web. -from Authors

dc:title: Turnover in the avifauna of Guana Island, British Virgin Islands
dc:creator: Mayer G.C.
dc:description: The land birds of Guana Island (299 ha) were surveyed each year from 1984 through 1990. Earlier surveys were made in 1954 and 1986. During this time, no species of bird became established on the island. One established species, Dendroica petechia, became extinct, attributable to habitat destruction. There were no instances of equilibrium turnover. Tropical birds may have lower turnover rates because they are more sedentary, have lower adult mortality, and are more often resident, rather than migratory. Alternatively, the position of Guana Island within an archipelago of numerous small islands may lead to a metapopulation structure which greatly reduces the probability of local extinction. -from Authors

dc:title: Density-dependent clutch size caused by habitat heterogeneity
dc:creator: Dhondt A.
dc:description: In some studies but no in others average clutch size decreases with density. The authors propose that density-dependent fecundity occurs because, as density increases, proportionally more poor-quality sites (with small clutches) are occupied, and not because the clutch size in all territories decreases. This mechanism will only cause density dependence if the habitat is heterogeneous at the scale of the home range or territory of an individual. Density-dependent fecundity will be found in some populations but not in others because of differences in the scale of habitat heterogeneity. Results from an experimental study on blue tits Parus caeruleus support the hypothesis. -Authors

dc:title: Population biology of Heligmosomoides polygyrus (Nematoda) in the wood mouse
dc:creator: Gregory R.
dc:description: Examines the interaction between Apodemus sylvaticus and the intestinal nematode Heligmosomoides polygyrus using data collected at Tollymore Park Forest, Co. Down, Northern Ireland. Some 86% of mice were infected by H. polygyrus. Mean worm burden was c12 worms per mouse. Worm burdens did not differ with sex. Parasites were highly overdispersed within the host population. Worm burdens increased in the youngest mouse age-classes, reaching the highest value in mice around eight months old and then declined in older age groups. The "convex' shape of age-intensity curves was similar in male and female wood mice. Parasite prevalence was highest around April and intensity around May. The mouse population was at its "youngest' from late summer into winter and "oldest' in the late spring. Convexity may be created by acquired immunity and/or by parasite-induced host mortality. -from Authors

dc:title: The role of energy intake rate in prey and habitat selection of common eiders Somateria mollissima in winter: a risk-sensitive interpretation
dc:creator: Guillemette M.
dc:description: In the Gulf of St Lawrence, wintering eiders forage on a variety of prey types from several distinct habitats, kelp beds, urchin barrens and beds of the phaeophyate Agarum cribrosum. In kelp beds eiders feed mostly on small blue mussels Mytilus edulis. Over barrens they capture green sea urchins Strongylocentrotus droebachiensis, and over Agarum beds they feed on both spider crabs Hyas araneus and urchins. All sizes of flocks feed in the kelp beds, whereas mostly small flocks fed in the barrens and Agarum beds. Small-flock individuals strongly select mussels and crabs whereas urchins are non-preferred prey. Dive and foraging cycles differ significantly according to the above three habitats. Although, the size, density and energy content of prey differ markedly between kelp and Agarum beds, these two habitats offer an even energy return. However, the variance in energy return in these two habitats differs strikingly, being greater in the latter. The author hypothesized, in the context of risk foraging theory, that this was related to flock sizes and body condition. As predicted, individuals feeding in small flocks were in bad condition compared to individuals feeding in large flocks. This suggests that small-flock individuals are seeking the habitat offering a variable intake to improve their survival probability. -from Authors

dc:title: On the augmentation of ring recovery data with field information
dc:creator: Freeman S.
dc:description: The estimate of the survival probability for first-year birds, obtained from radio-marked birds alone, may not correspond to the overall maximum-likelihood estimate of this probability. The authors explain how such a discrepancy may arise, and show that, in this case, one of the other parameters in the model is estimated on a boundary to the parameter space. -from Authors

dc:title: An investigation of population limitation using factorial experiments
dc:creator: Mitchell P.
dc:description: Most populations undergo multiple-factor limitation. This raises the question of whether the different factors combine additively or interactively. Results of two factorial experiments involving Drosophila melanogaster are presented, one based on a series of resource variables, the second includes presence/absence of a natural enemy. Results of the first experiment show widespread interactive effects. In the second there is a general lack of interaction. -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of supplemental food on snowshoe hare reproduction and juvenile growth at a cyclic population peak
dc:creator: O'Donoghue M.
dc:description: Lepus americanus populations were provided with supplemental food on two study grids in SW Yukon. Timing of parturition, pregnancy rates, litter sizes, male breeding coniditon, and juvenile growth rates were measured on two food grids and on two control grids during two summers at a cyclic peak in hare numbers. Most female hares gave birth to three litters per summer, and parturition was in approximate synchrony, such that there were three distinct litter groups per season. The main effects of food addition were to increase hare densities 2.1-2.7-fold, advance the timing of breeding by c1 wk in 1 yr, and increase pregnancy rates by 5% relative to the controls, There were no significant differences in litter sizes, lengths of male breeding seasons, juvenile growth rates, or total female reproductive output between hares on the food and control grids. Third litter stillborn rates were higher, and third litter juvenile growth rates slightly lower on food grids relative to those on controls, possibly reflecting an effect of higher densities. Results suggest that food is not a proximate factor limiting hare reproduction and early juvenile growth at the observed peak hare densities. -from Authors

dc:title: Nesting density and breeding success of golden eagles in relation to food supply in Scotland
dc:creator: Watson J.
dc:description: Nesting density and breeding success of Aquila chrysaetos were measured in six areas across Scotland in 1982-85 and in three additional test areas in 1985. An index of food abundance was obtained. In the original six areas, nesting density ranged from 14.7-26.1 pairs per 1000km2 and breeding success from 0.19-1.00 chicks fledged per pair per year. Nesting density was positively correlated with amount of carrion (dead sheep and deer) detected on transects, and breeding success was positively correlated with the amount of live prey. Implications of land-use changes for golden eagle nesting ecology are discussed. -from Authors

dc:title: Density-dependent mating success and colour polymorphism in females of the damselfly Ischnura graellsii (Odonata: Coenagrionidae)
dc:creator: Cordero A.
dc:description: Female-limited colour polymorphism is very common in odonates. One of the forms has male-like colouring (androchromotypics), while the other(s) is cryptic (gynochromotypics). Three hypotheses have been proposed to explain the maintenance of this polymorphism: 1) higher reproductive isolation of androchromotypics, balanced by higher predation on this form; 2) androchromotypics avoid unnecessary long matings, but suffer greater predation; and 3) androchromotypics avoid male harassment at high density, but have lower mating success at low density. Survivorship and mating success of andro- and gynochromotypic females of Ischnura graellsii were measured in two natural populations with different densities in Galicia (NW Spain). Contrary to the predictions of hypotheses 1 and 2, mean longevity and daily survival rate was the same for andro- and gynochromotypics. Mating success was the same for andro- and gynochromotypics at high density but the proportion of unmated females was greater in andro- than gynochromotypics at low density. Androchromotypics mated with longer inter-copula intervals at high density, and mating duration was also density-dependent. Results suggest that hypothesis 3 is the most appropriate to explain the maintenance of the polymorphism. Androchromotypics were larger than gynochromotypics in the high density population. As body size is related to larval nourishment, this suggests an effect of larval competition on the maintenance of polymorphism. -from Author

dc:title: Predator-prey relationships: the impact of lion predation of wildebeest and zebra populations
dc:creator: Mills M.
dc:description: The role of Panthera leo predation in the dynamics of blue wildebeest Connochaetes taurinus and zebra Equus burchelli populations was investigated through simulation models. Data used in the models were from observations in SE Kruger National Park. Model 1 ascertained the number of killing lions (adult females) that could be supported by each prey population while remaining stable. A single model was constructed for the sedentary wildebeest population. A summer and winter model was constructed for the semi-migratory zebra population. The sensitivity of the parameters in the model was tested by changing their value by 10%. In model 2, the kill age structure for each species was changed to determine the number of killing lions the altered prey selection parameters could support. There was no difference in the vulnerability of either species to predation. Zebra foals (<1 yr) were killed more frequently than expected. No selection for sex or by season could be found for either species. Model 1 predicted that the wildebeest population stabilizes with 7.7 killing lions, close to the number in the study area. The winter zebra populations stabilizes with 6.8 killing lions and the summer zebra population with 19.4. Manipulation of kill rate followed by adult fecundity rate had the greatest effect on population size of both species. In model 2, wildebeest predation was made selective towards calves and zebra predation was made non-selective for sex and age. With these parameters the wildebeest population stabilizes with 10.7 killing lions and the zebra population with 5.4 in winter and 15.1 in summer. The models suggest that lion predation affected wildebeest more severely than zebra during the study. This was through the way in which lions selected their prey, and because of the sedentary behaviour of the wildebeest, as opposed to the semi-migratory behaviour of the zebra. -from Authors

dc:title: Territory quality, parental effort and reproductive success of oystercatchers (Haematopus ostralegus)
dc:creator: Ens B.J.
dc:description: Oystercatchers that breed on the saltmarsh of the Frisian island of Schiermonnikoog occupy two different type sof territory. In "resident' territories the nesting area and the feeding area are adjacent. In "leapfrog' territories the nesting area and the feeding area are separated by distances of 200-500m. Between 1984-1989, residents fledged on average 3.5 times as many chicks per year as leapfrogs. The discrepancy in fledgling production arose primarily through increased mortality of leapfrog chicks due to starvation. Presence of a sibling reduced the probability of fledging for leapfrog chicks, but not for resident chicks, providing further evidence that leapfrog chicks competed for a limited food supply. Leapfrog parents fledged fewer chicks, not because of poor feeding conditions in their feeding territory (intake rates of leapfrogs exceeded those of residents), but because they failed to transport a sufficient amount of food to the chicks. To supply their chicks with the same amount of food as did residents, leapfrog parents should have spent c4000 s per low water period in transport flights: no leapfrog parent ever reached this level of effort. -from Authors

dc:title: Spatial density dependence in populations of a cynipid gall-former Andricus quercuscalicis
dc:creator: Hails R.
dc:description: Patterns of spatial density dependence in mortality factors affecting the sexual generation of Andricus quercuscalicis on Quercus cerris were investigated. In field data, statistically significant spatial density dependence was detected in c15% of cases. Out of 62 cases of significant density dependence, 66% were of inverse density dependence. In particular, the gall wasp data demonstrate a preponderance of inverse density dependence in rates of parasitism. Only predation of galls by birds exhibited a consistent pattern of direct density dependence. There was marked variation in the intensity of all mortality factors from tree to tree. As spatial scale is increased from catkins, through buds, shoots and twigs, so the sample size declines and the range of densities increases. Enhancing gall densities by caging agamic females directly onto the branches of the host tree led to an increase in mean gall density and in the range of gall densities. This, in turn, led to an increase in the detection of inverse density dependence (mainly through parasitoid attack) but had no significant impact on the detection of direct density dependence. Data are consistent with the hypothesis of an environment which is patchy with respect to the nature of population regulation: there may be a small number of regulated subpopulations, linked by dispersal to a much larger number of unregulated subpopulations. -from Authors

dc:title: Do parasites make prey vulnerable to predation? Red grouse and parasites
dc:creator: Hudson P.
dc:description: Lagopus lagopus scoticus killed by predators in spring and summer had significantly greater burdens of the caecal nematode Trichostrongylus tenuis than those shot during the autumn. Grouse that appeared to have died through the effects of parasites carried greater worm burdens than grouse killed by predators. The proportion of grouse with high levels of parasite infection increased with intensity of predator control. These two empirical observations suggest that predators selectively prey on heavily infected grouse. Female grouse with large parasite burdens may emit more scent and may be more vulnerable to mammalian predation. A modified mathematical model of the grouse-nematode system is described which incorporates the effects of both random and selective predation of heavily parasitized grouse. An analysis of the model illustrates the importance of interactions between grouse, parasites and predators in determining the relative densities of each. When predators selectively remove heavily parasitized individuals, then low levels of predation can lead to increases in the size of the host (or prey) population. -from Authors

dc:title: The population dynamics of Heligmosomoides polygyrus in an enclosure population of wood mice
dc:creator: Quinnell R.
dc:description: The population dynamics of the gastrointestinal nematode Heligmosomoides polygyrus were studied in a mixed-sex enclosed population of Apodemus sylvaticus. Prevalence of infection was 100% in both December 1988 and June 1989. The geometric mean worm burden was 40 and 74 worms per host respectively. The age-intensity profile of infection was monotonic at both times. Significant resistance to reinfection was found in adult mice, but not young mice, in June 1989. There was a significant negative correlation in adult mice between worm burden in June and resistance to reinfection. Per capita worm fecundity decreased sharply with host age and resistance to reinfection, but was positively correlated with worm density, especially in older mice. Worm sex ratio also varied with host age and resistance, becoming more male-biased in older, resistant hosts. The frequency distributions of worm burdens were overdispersed in December, in June and after challenge, and could be described by negative binomial distributions with aggregation parameters, k, of 2.11, 1.26 and 1.24 respectively. Degree of aggregation increased with host age. The relative contributions of variation in acquired resistance and exposure in generating overdispersion in this system are discussed. -from Author

dc:title: Seasonality, predation, and the behaviour of a tropical mainland anole
dc:creator: Lister B.
dc:description: Examined Anolis nebulosus in a deciduous forest at Chamela on the Pacific coast of Mexico. This area has a severe 6-7 month dry season and the largest seasonal fluctuations in arthropod numbers and biomass yet recorded for a tropical habitat. The A. nebulosus population in the Chamela forest experiences high predation rates and low annual survivorship. In response to the wet season flush of insects, males and females shift from ground to arboreal foraging and increase feeding rates 5-10-fold. Males also travel further to capture prey and change their foraging mode, switching from trunk-ground, sit-and-wait foraging in the dry season to trunk-crown, mobile foraging in the wet season. During the dry season, male and female A. nebulosus are the most sedentary lizards known, moving only once or twice per hour, and travelling a maximum of 8-9 m day-1. During the wet season females are 2-3 times and males 5-10 times more active. Following the brief breeding period, however, both males and females retreat into unexposed hiding places and are emergent and active for only 1 or 2 days week-1. This reclusive behaviour and the exceptional levels of inactivity found in this species are most likely adaptations that reduce the risk of predation. During the wet season breeding period, males increase display rates 15-30-fold and expand their home ranges 10-15-fold. Compared to insular populations, however, Chamela males invest significantly less time courting females (49% vs. 95%) and more time hiding and resting (44% vs. 1%). Such differences suggest that mainland males are trading off the probability of encountering and mating with females for enhanced safety. Females devote more time to foraging than males during both wet and dry seasons. This may enhance female fitness by increasing growth rate, fat reserves, and egg production. Males divide their time equally between resting/hiding and foraging and allocate only a small proportion of their day to social activities, except during the breeding period when the majority of their time and energy is invested in reproductive behaviour. -from Authors

dc:title: Dirichlet tessellation of bark beetle spatial attack points
dc:creator: Byers J.
dc:description: The program and relationship were used to analyse the spatial attack patterns of the bark beetles Dendroctonus brevicornis, Tomicus piniperda and Pityogenes chalcographus. All three species exhibited spacing between attack sites, in agreement with known behavioural mechanisms that are proposed for avoiding intraspecific competition for food resources. -from Author

dc:title: Daily energy expenditure and water flux of free-living Blanford's foxes (Vulpes cana), a small desert carnivore
dc:creator: Geffen E.
dc:description: Blanford's fox is a small canid that inhabits rocky mountains and canyons in the deserts of Israel, where it feeds mainly on invertebrates and fruits. The authors measured daily energy expenditure and water intake of free-living Blanford's foxes and compared the results with those of kit fox Vulpes macrotis and estimated dietary intake and seasonal activity periods. Blanford's foxes maintained water and energy balances on a diet of invertebrates and fruits without the need to drink. Metabolism during activity was 8.4 times higher than at rest, and daily energy expenditure of Blanford's foxes was, on average 30.1% higher than that of the kit fox. This result was compatible with the prediction that activity is more energetically expensive for Blanford's foxes in their mountainous habitat than in another desert fox species that inhabits flat terrains. -from Authors

dc:title: Patterns of density dependence in moths and aphids
dc:creator: Woiwod I.
dc:description: The incidence of density dependence was examined in 5715 time-series of annual abundances of 447 species of moths and aphids in the UK using Ricker equation, Bulmer's test and Pollard et al.'s test. Delayed density dependence (lag 2 yr) was not found more frequently than expected by chance. In the moth family Noctuidae, delayed density dependence was slightly but significantly more frequent in woodland populations than in non-woodland populations, consistent with a higher frequency of outbreak species among forest Lepidoptera. Incidence of significant density dependence increased with the length of the time-series (from 10-24 yr), and density dependence was detected more frequently in species which did not show a significant trend in abundance over time. Incidence of density dependence was 79% and 88% in moth and aphid time-series which were >20 yr (Bulmer's test). There were only slight differences between localities in the average degree of density dependence when the effects of time-series length and trend were removed. In noctuids, average degree of density dependence increased with body size. -from Authors

dc:title: The spatial dynamics of host-parasitoid systems
dc:creator: Comins H.
dc:description: The authors consider models for host-parasitoid interactions in spatially patchy environments, where in each generation specified fractions of the host and parasitoid subpopulations in each patch move to adjacent patches. In most previous work of this general kind, the movement is not localized in this way, but involves "global' mixing of the populations prior to dispersal. A remarkable range of dynamical behaviour is exhibited by a mathematically explicit model with constant host reproductive rate, deterministically unstable local dynamics and dispersing hosts and parasitoids that only move to nearest neighbour patches in a density-independent way. Density of the host and parasitoid subpopulations in a two-dimensional array of patches may exhibit complex patterns of spiral waves, spatial chaos, a so-called static "crystal lattice' pattern, or they may become extinct. The probability of extinction rises rapidly when the number of patches present decreases below some characteristic arena size which varies with the scale of the spatial dynamics. The different types of spatial dynamics depends critically on the fractions of hosts and adult parasitoids that disperse in each generation from the patches in which they emerged. Low rates of host dispersal tend to lead to chaotic patterns unless this rate is very low and parasitoid dispersal rates very high, in which case "crystal lattice' patterns may occur. Intermediate to high rates of host dispersal tend to result in spiral patterns. -from Authors

dc:title: Foraging of the great crested grebe in relation to food supply
dc:creator: Ulenaers P.
dc:description: Foraging data for Podiceps cristatus feeding in shallow fish-ponds (0.8-1m deep) were used to test whether pond characteristics, fish density mean wet weight of the fish or fish species influenced foraging behaviour and success in this fish-eating grebe. When fishing for roach/rudd (Rutilus rutilus/Scardinius erythropthalmus), the number of prey eaten per unit time foraging was positively influenced by the proportion of successful dives, and negatively by the mean diving time. The proportion of successful dives increased as fish weight decreased. Mean diving time, however, was not related to any component of the food supply, nor to pond characteristics. When roach/rudd were the prey, handling time above the water did not constrain the number of prey eaten per unit time foraging at any fish density. With roach/rudd and carp Cyprinus carpio as prey, the above-water handling time increased with the size of the fish consumed. Total handling time under and above the water surface together constituted on average 4.7% of the time required to consume one fish. When fishing for roach/rudd, successful dives lasted significantly longer than unsuccessful ones. As mean duration of successful dives increased with fish weight, this can be explained by handling prey under water. For carp, however, this could not be shown. Furthermore, unsuccessful dives lasted significantly longer when fishing for carp than for roach/rudd, probably related to behavioural differences between the fish species. In roach/rudd ponds, grebes took on average the smaller fish. -from Authors

dc:title: Nutritional constraints on egg formation in the lesser black-backed gull: an experimental study
dc:creator: Bolton M.
dc:description: Investigated the nutritional requirements of egg formation in Larus fuscus. Provision of additional food on the nesting territories did not result in a decrease in the amount of time spent away from the colony by females, although fish-fed males did spend more time on territory during the early part of the pre-laying period in a year of normal food supply. Courtship feeding rates were very low in comparison with other studies and were not influenced by provision of additional food. In a year of apparent low food availability, clutch size was depressed by protein, but not energy, limitation. Egg production may further be limited by the supply of specific nutrients, contained in the egg, but not present in sufficient quantity in the fish supplement. There was on advancement in laying dates of fed birds compared with controls in the same year, suggesting that clutch size may not be primarily determined by laying date in lesser black-backed gulls. Chicks hatching from the eggs laid by females receiving an egg supplement prior to laying tended to be skeletally larger and heavier on hatching, but any potential advantages of hatching from larger eggs were short-lived. There was no difference in subsequent growth or survival of chicks of egg-fed parents compared with controls. -from Authors

dc:title: Comparative ecology of Neotropical bird lice (Insecta: Phthiraptera)
dc:creator: Clayton D.
dc:description: Data were collected in the Andean foothills of SE Peru. Birds representing 127 species in 26 families were sampled for lice; 47.7% birds were parasitized, with a mean intensity of 6.6 lice per bird and a mean richness of 1.1 louse species per host species. Nearly all louse species were restricted to a single species of host (monoxenous). Thirteen metapopulations of lice (10%) had significantly skewed sex ratios, of which four were skewed toward males, representing the first male-biased sex ratios reported for chewing lice; 34 metapopulations (27%) had significantly skewed age ratios and showed an overall bias toward adults. Non-quantitative host-parasite records are reported for lice collected from additional birds representing 45 species in 20 families. -from Authors

dc:title: Modelling gypsy moth-virus-leaf chemistry interactions: implications of plant quality for pest and pathogen dynamics
dc:creator: Foster M.
dc:description: The decline phase in the population dynamics of Lymantria dispar (Lepidoptera: Lymantriidae) is associated both with nuclear polyhedrosis virus epizootics and greater phenolics levels in preferred hosts such as red oak Quercus rubra. Recent studies have shown that hydrolysable tannins in red oak reduce both gypsy moth (GM) fecundity and virus susceptibility. The most realistic gypsy moth dynamics required moderate to high levels of tannin (30-45%), low non-virus mortality (3.0 per GM per year), and long-lived virus (1 yr). For simulations with low non-virus mortality and long-lived virus, the ratio of highest to lowest population density increased from 10-fold at 10% tannin to over 1000-fold at 40% tannin, then stabilized with little or no fluctuation at 50% tannin. The shift to stability at 50% tannin results from the lower sensitivity of fecundity than virus to hydrolysable tannins and a consequent decrease in the difference between virus pathogenicity and the gypsy moth's intrinsic rate of increase at high tannin levels. The dynamics generated agree well with predictions of the Anderson & May (1981) model that stable limit cycles are promoted by 1) longer-lived virus and 2) high pathogenicity relative to the intrinsic rate of increase. Simulations suggest that the net effect of moderate constant tannin levels over multiple generations will be destabilizing compared with low and high tannin levels. -from Authors

dc:title: Relationships between social status, otolith size at first feeding and subsequent growth in Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar)
dc:creator: Metcalfe N.
dc:description: Otolith size was not related to fish size at first feeding, but was related to dominance status, dominant fish having larger otoliths. Both otolith size and dominance status at first feeding were good predictors of fish size 3 months later (in turn, a good predictor of age at smolt migration). Variation in metabolic rate may influence both otolith size at first feeding and dominance; dominant individuals would have a greater potential for growth, so producing a correlation between initial otolith size and subsequent growth rates. This would result in a connection between metabolic rate and age at migration. -from Authors

dc:title: Optimization of territory shape in heterogeneous habitats: a field study of the red-capped cardinal (Paroaria gularis)
dc:creator: Eason P.
dc:description: Models developed to examine two factors that may influence optimal territory shape in heterogeneous habitats (resource availability and defence costs) were tested using a population of red-capped cardinals in Manu National Park, SE Peru. Cardinals defend territories along the shores of oxbow lakes and rivers, with each territory containing two short stretches of shore that are on opposite sides of the water. Analysis of samples of arthropod prey showed no differences between the two shores, allowing the foraging model to be rejected and indicating that resource distributions do not determine the shape of the cardinals' territories. The probability of detecting an intruder on the same shore decreased with increasing distance from the territory owner. Intruders on the shore opposite the territorial pair were more likely to be detected immediately than were intruders on the same shore. Intruders detected immediately were easier to evict than intruders that were not detected immediately, and intruders tended to avoid the shore opposite the territorial pair. Data supported the defence model: reduction in defence costs due to increased intruder detectability appears to be the factor that favours the inclusion of two shores in each cardinal territory. In patchy habitats, the effects of defence costs may result in territories that are suboptimally shaped for foraging. -from Author

dc:title: Early development and population fluctuations in Soay sheep
dc:creator: Clutton-Brock T.
dc:description: In the Soay sheep Ovis aries population of Hirta (St Kilda), high winter mortality occurs every 3-4 yr. During these die-offs, >50% of adults, 70% of yearlings and 90% of lambs die and population density falls by c65%. Individual differences in birth weight and subsequent growth rates exert a strong influence on the survival of lambs throughout the neonatal period and through the first winter of life when the effects of population density on survival have been taken into account. High population density in summer is associated with reductions in the weight of lambs entering the winter and low birth weights the following spring. Density-related changes in birth weight are closely correlated with changes in neonatal mortality, but annual variation in neonatal mortality contributes little to fluctuations in population size. Desite the relationship between individual variation in birth weight and survival through the first winter, density-related changes in the weight of lambs at birth and at four months contributed little to density-related changes in survival through the first winter, primarily because birth weight and early growth were most heavily depressed in springs that followed die-offs and were followed by winters when mortality (and density) were low. Density-related changes in lamb growth, are thus unlikely to be an important cause of die-offs. -from Authors

dc:title: The influence of river flow rate on the breeding behaviour of Calopteryx damselflies
dc:creator: Gibbons D.
dc:description: Calopteryx splendens xanthostoma and C. haemorrhoidalis were studied in two freshwater streams in S France. Females of both species preferred to oviposit in aquatic vegetation found in fast-flowing water. Most ovipositions by C.s. xanthostoma occurred in a single species, and female C. haemorrhoidalis ceased ovipositing in an area of fast water after the flow was slowed. Males of both species defended areas of oviposition vegetation as territories. Territorial disputes were common in fast-flowing parts of the streams; slow-flowing areas were often undefended. Male C. haemorrhoidalis deserted previously defended areas after a decrease in flow rate. The mating success of male C.s. xanthostoma inceased with the rate of flow of water through their territory, but only up to a rate of 0.15 m s-1. Above this, males spend so much time in territorial defence that they probably missed mating opportunities. Males of both species sometimes courted females by falling onto the water surface and floating with the current. Males that performed this display had a higher mating success than those that did not. This display may have evolved to indicate territory quality to females. -from Authors

dc:title: Laying date in the coot: effects of age and mate choice
dc:creator: Perdeck A.C.
dc:description: Laying data in Fulica atra advanced with age of both the male and the female. Individual females had different but rather constant laying dates. After controlling for these differences, the effect of female age on laying date remained, but that of male age disappeared, implying: 1) that both early and late females advanced their laying date when becoming older, and 2) that male age has no direct effect on laying date, but that older males are better able to compete for early-laying females. Data supported neither increased reproductive effort with age (residual reproductive value hypothesis), nor differential delay of reproduction between early and late females (delayed reproduction hypothesis) as additional explanations for the advancement of laying date with age. This advancement in the individual female is therefore considered to be due to increasing quality (maturation hypothesis). The repeatability of laying date in females was 0.32, but the heritability, estimated with daughter- mother regression, was only 0.02, ie the variation in laying date between individuals is predominantly environmental. -from Authors

dc:title: Regulation and stability of a free-living host-parasite system: Trichostrongylus tenuis in red grouse. I. Monitoring and parasite reduction experiments
dc:creator: Hudson P.
dc:description: Intensive population studies were conducted for 10 yr on Lagopus lagopus scoticus and the parasitic nematode Trichostrongylus tenuis in N England. Winter loss was the key factor determining changes in grouse numbers, although breeding losses were also important. T. tenuis had an aggregated distribution within the adult grouse population, even though the degree of aggregation was relatively low compared with other parasite systems. Recruitment of parasites into the adult worm population was dependent on grouse density. Both winter loss and breeding losses were correlated with intensity of parasite infection. Experimental reduction in parasite burdens consistently increased breeding production and winter survival of grouse. The red grouse-T. tenuis system exhibits three conditions that will generate population cycles: 1) parasite-induced reduction in grouse breeding production; 2) a low degree of parasite aggregation within the grouse population; and 3) time delays in parasite recruitment. -from Authors

dc:title: The value of male parental care and its influence on reproductive allocation by male and female dunnocks
dc:creator: Davies N.
dc:description: In Prunella modularis, male help became increasingly valuable as brood size increased, but addition of one male's help increased success more than addition of a second male's help. Removal experiments confirmed that differences in reproductive success were caused by differences in male help. Females laid a larger clutch when they expected two males' full-time help than when expected male help was less. A polygynous male preferred to invest full-time in one brood rather than part-time in both. In polygynandry, where two males shared two females, each male preferred to feed at different nests rather than to both help one brood and leave the other unaided. In polygynandry, a male chose to feed the brood of the female with whom he had gained a greater share of the matings (and hence paternity), but mating share did not influence the provisioning rate of a lone male helping a female: he worked equally hard whether he gained all or just a share of the matings. Males preferred mating to chick feeding and, with two fertile males, spent most time with the female closest to laying. With choices involving trade-offs between two mating efforts, two parental efforts, or mating versus parental effort, males chose the option which led to greater reproductive success. -from Authors

dc:title: Modification of anti-predator behaviour in tadpoles by environmental conditioning
dc:creator: Semlitsch R.
dc:description: Examined the anti-predator behaviour of Rana lessonae and Rana esculenta. Eggs were hatched in the laboratory and tadpoles were conditioned for 30 days to fish, newts, odonates and Bufo tadpoles. Rana esculenta tadpoles spent more time swimming than did R. lessonae tadpoles, but species did not differ in refuge use. Time spent swimming was highest in tadpoles conditioned to Bufo tadpoles and lowest in those conditioned the three predators. Time spent in the refuge was highest in tadpoles conditioned to fish, newts, and odonates and lowest in those conditioned to tadpoles. R. esculenta spent more time swimming when conditioned to tadpoles; R. lessonae spent less time swimming when conditioned to odonates than the other species. Tadpoles exposed to fish predators increased time spent in the refuge compared to odonates, newts, and the tadpole and water controls. There was a significant conditioning × predator interaction on swimming and open-water use. R. lessonae and R. esculenta tadpoles thus possess inherited differences in anti-predator behaviour which may be interpreted as general adaptations to aquatic environments, but conditioning to predators can modify (fine-tune) their response to specific environments. -from Authors

dc:title: Spring body condition, fecundity and survival in female willow ptarmigan
dc:creator: Robb L.A.
dc:description: Examined variation in spring body mass (adjusted for structural size and number of days before clutch initiation) and its relationship with measures of fecundity and survival for populations of female willow ptarmigan at La Perouse Bay (LPB), Manitoba (Lagopus lagopus albus) and Chilkat Pass (CP) British Columbia (Lagopus lagopus alexandrae). Adult and yearling hen ptarmigan showed an increase in body mass during spring at both LPB and CP. Although hens at LPB had greater body mass than hens at CP there were no differences in patterns of body mass gain attributable to either years, age-classes, or sites. No differences were found in measures of fecundity or survival between yearlings (1 yr of age) in good and poor condition at both sites. At CP, adult (2+ yr of age) hens in good condition produced heavy chicks, were more likely to be monogamous, and were more likely to return to the study area in subsequent years than hens in poor condition. Hens in good condition at LPB had higher return rates the following year than those in poor condition but showed no differences in fecundity. As measures of fecundity were not related to a hen's spring body condition, hens in poor condition probably invest relatively more in reproduction than those in good condition. Return of yearling hens was not related to their body condition in spring, but the authors did observe low return rates of adult hens in poor condition. The "cost' of reproduction to females may be cumulative over years. -Authors

dc:title: The ecology of the hen flea Ceratophyllus gallinae and the moorhen flea Dasypsyllus gallinulae in nestboxes
dc:creator: Harper G.
dc:description: Populations of fleas from nests of seven species of bird were measured over a 10-year period. The hen flea is more abundant in nests of tits than of pied flycatcher Ficedula hypoleuca and redstart Phoenicurus phoenicurus. The moorhen flea is more abundant in marsh tit Parus palustris, coal tit Parus ater and redstart nests than in pied flycatcher and other tit nests. There is no evidence of competition between the two fleas. The date the birds start nest-building, and/or the length of time the nest is maintained above air temperature, is important in determining population size in the hen flea, but not in the moorhen flea. Hen fleas disperse from overwintering sites in nestboxes early in the birds' breeding season and find hosts mostly among blue tits. The population of hen fleas in pied flycatcher nests is closely related to the number of blue tits Parus caeruleus breeding, suggesting that the numbers of fleas arriving in the nest is a significant factor in pied flycatcher. Another important determinant of population size in both flea species is the number of generations produced in the season, though other factors seem to be limiting at high population densities in the nest. Two generations are the norm in blue tit and great tit Parus major nests, but are less frequent in pied flycatcher nests. Factors controlling populations of moorhen fleas remain obscure, though appear to be significantly different from those controlling the hen flea. One-fifth of nests probably do not receive any fertilized females of this species at all, whereas virtually all nests are colonized by the hen flea. -Authors

dc:title: Hatching success of lapwings on farmland: differences between habitats and colonies of different sizes
dc:creator: Berg A.
dc:description: At a farmland site dominated by cereal crops in C Sweden, the most important factor causing breeding failures in Vanellus vanellus was farming operations, which accounted for 85% of all nest losses. Difference in hatching success between habitats; unsown tillage (9% hatching success), sown tillage (78%), fallow fields (31%) and grassland (67% hatching success) was an effect of different farming practices. Only 13% of the females were estimated to hatch a first clutch, but 66% of females that lost the first clutch was estimated to lay a replacement clutch (67% hatching success), giving an estimated proportion of 55% females hatching a clutch. Predation accounted for 14% of nest losses. Predation risk was negatively correlated to the number of close neighbours, ie density of nests in the colony was very important. There was also a general anti-predator effect on large colonies, which was independent of the number of close neighbours, since nests in large colonies (>5 nests) were less likely to be robbed than solitary nests and nests in small colonies (2-5 nests). Nest survival was higher at sites far (>50 m) from trees or other perches suitable for avian predators than at those situated close to these perches. Lapwings seemed to mimize the influence of avian predators by breeding in aggregations: 92% of nests were found in colonies (up to 28 nests), and preferring nest sites far away from perches for avian predators. Paradoxically, lapwings preferred to breed on tillage, which (when unsown) was the habitat with most net losses, but a majority of the failed breeders laid a replacement clutch and 57% of the females hatch a clutch in tillage, which is slightly better than in other habitats. -from Authors

dc:title: The effects of food availability and foraging constraint on the life history of a predatory leech, Nephelopsis obscura
dc:creator: Dratnal E.
dc:description: Two groups of Nephelopsis obscura, fed ad lib on Tubifex tubifex, were compared: one was maintained in an environment with a mud substratum (MS) allowing prey anti-predator responses, the other without a substratum (NS) providing prey directly available to the leech. NS leeches showed a 4.7 times higher feeding rate and 3.7 times higher growth rate than MS leeches resulting in NS leeches attaining maturity at a mean size of 750 mg after 85 days compared to a mean size at maturity of 270 mg after 109 days for MS leeches. Direct observation of foraging behaviour revealed three foraging modes: immediate prey ingestion; delayed prey ingestion; and no prey ingestion after encounter. The change from the immediate to delayed foraging mode resulted in a threshold above which successful foraging on prey with a mud substratum became impossible. Feeding on directly vulnerable prey without a substratum continued until the gut capacity was reached. The life-history traits exhibited by NS leeches result from the potential for feeding to gut capacity while the life-history traits of MS leeches result from the timetables imposed by the foraging constraint. Based on instantaneous feeding and growth rates of similar sizes of NS and MS leeches, coefficient of size-specific feeding ability loss and growth ability loss were calculated for constrained MS leeches and shown to be an increasing function of leech size (weight). -from Authors

dc:title: Spring declines in Microtus pennsylvanicus and the role of steroid hormones
dc:creator: Boonstra R.
dc:description: Tested the hypothesis that meadow voles from populations experiencing severe spring decline should exhibit severe stress responses as indicated by high free corticosterone levels, using three populations in S Ontario. Stress responses, however, were apparently not related to population demography in the study and the authors reject the Christian stress hypothesis and the adaptive stress hypothesis of Lee and Cockburn as explanations for spring declines in this species. They propose an adaptive model to account for the differences in the hormonal response to breeding between species in which the males are semelparous and those in which males are iteroparous. -from Authors

dc:title: A modelling study of the population dynamics of a large blue butterfly, Maculinea rebeli, a parasite of red ant nests
dc:creator: Hochberg M.
dc:description: Developed a mathematical population model for Maculinea rebeli based on its dependence on two sequential resources, the cross-leaved gentian Gentiana cruciata and red ant Myrmica schencki. The model has two main biological components: 1) recruitment and competition on the plant for the first few weeks of butterfly life, and 2) recruitment by and competition within nests of the red ant for the remainder of the butterfly life-cycle. Parameters for the model are based in part on data collected from the Spanish Pyrenees. The model is used to evaluate how different ecological processes and densities of the plant and ant resources may affect the butterfly population, including its density, resilience from perturbation, and persistence. For the Spanish study site, survival of the butterfly in ant nests is disproportionately more important to its population than is competition on the plant. Changes in the observed population of the plant have virtually no impact on the butterfly population. Future studies should take account for instance of changes in the density of ant nests and the population of a specialist ichneumonid parasitoid. -from Authors

dc:title: Spatial dynamics of a patchily distributed butterfly species
dc:creator: Thomas C.
dc:description: Nine metapopulations of the silver-studded blue Plebejus argus were mapped in N Wales in 1983 and 1990. Five metapopulations occurred in heathland, one in mossland and three in limestone grassland. Within metapopulations, local distributions of the butterfly corresponded to the spatial distributions of suitable habitat: P. argus was able to colonize virtually all suitable habitat patches <1km from existing, populated patches. The regional distribution was constrained by the inability of the butterfly to colonize suitable habitat that was further than a few kilometres from existing metapopulations; some of these sites are now populated by P. argus following successful introductions. Turnover (extinctions and colonizations) of patches within metapopulations was relatively high in small patches. Turnover was also greater in heathland than in limestone; the principal reason for this was that patches of habitat were usually smaller in heathland, and small patches had high turnover in both biotopes. Turnover of area was greater in heathland, where the butterfly occupies relatively transient successional habitats, than in limestone grassland where the habitat can be maintained in a suitable condition for longer periods. The persistence of this spatially dynamic species depends on some suitable habitat being continuously available within relatively large areas of biotope. If the continuity is broken and a whole metapopulation becomes extinct, natural recolonization is unlikely to occur if the nearest P. argus source is more than a few kilometres away. -from Authors

dc:title: Species interactions, local and regional processes, and limits to the richness of ecological communities: a theoretical perspective
dc:creator: Cornell H.
dc:description: Asks whether local ecological communities ever saturated with species, ie whether they ever reach a point where species from the regional pool are unable to invade the local habitat because of exclusion by resident species. The authors review theoretical evidence for saturation in various community models and find that non-interactive models predict the absence of saturation as expected, but that interactive models do not uniformly predict saturation. Instead, models where coexistence is based on niche space heterogeneity predict saturation, whereas those where coexistence is based upon spatial heterogeneity yield mixed predictions. Thus, theory says that species interactions are a necessary but not sufficient condition for local saturation in ecological time. Unsaturated assemblages are likely to be ubiquitous in nature, and even saturated assemblages may not show hard limits to richness over evolutionary time-scales. If local richness is not often saturated, then regional richness is freed from local constraint, and other limits on regional richness (which, in turn, limit local richness) become important, including phylogenetic diversification over evolutionary time-scales. The principal direction of control for species richness appears to be from regional to local: then the key to community structure would lie in extrinsic biogeography rather than in intrinsic local processes, making community ecology a more historical science. -from Authors

dc:title: Correlates of the density of foraging oystercatchers Haematopus ostralegus at different population sizes
dc:creator: Goss-Custard J.
dc:description: Studied the distribution of oystercatchers on the Exe Estuary; the population varied temporally in size, feeding over beds of mussels Mytilus edulis, that varied spatially in quality. The mussel bed characteristics considered likely to correlate with bird density were: mussels densities of several length-classes and shell thickness on the dorsal and ventral sides) and beds (area, flatness, exposure time, proportion covered by algae, softness of the substrate and distance from the birds' high water roost). An initial multiple regression analysis relating bird density to these bed characteristics enabled three variables to be dismissed: exposure time, algal cover and flatness. Subsequent analysis of data from the 12 "priority' beds allowed more variables to be eliminated: densities of small and large mussels, shell thickness on the ventral side, and bed size. The four remaining variables (substrate softness, distance to roost, density of mussels 40-50 mm long and shell thickness on the dorsal side) together accounted for most of the explainable variation in bird density between the 12 priority beds. Multiple regressions of the logarithms of bird density against these four variables were calculated separately. In the presence of the other three variables, the effect of the density of 40-50 mm mussels was small at low population sizes but increased as bird numbers rose; at high population sizes, bird densities were higher where mussels were dense. At low population sizes, bird densities increased with shell thickness whereas, at high population sizes, they decreased with shell thickness. Bird densities were generally higher on beds far from the roost, particularly at the higher population sizes. The effect of substrate softness remained consistently large at all population sizes, and may even have increased: bird densities were markedly higher on beds with firm substrates on all except a few low population censuses. -from Authors

dc:title: Lifetime reproductive success and its correlates in the monogamous rodent, Peromyscus californicus
dc:creator: Ribble D.
dc:description: Investigated variation in lifetime reproductive success (LRS) between males and females in Peromyscus californicus at the Hastings Natural History Reservation, coastal California. Neither litter size nor interbirth interval changes in relation to parity (litter sequence), suggesting that reproductive success did not change with age. Interbirth intervals were significantly longer for individuals that re-mated compared to continuously mated individuals. As expected for a monogamous species, the mean and variance in LRS were statistically similar between males and females. Maximum weight and timing of first reproduction were significantly correlated with LRS. Significant selection gradients were observed on timing on first reproduction in males, and maximum weight in females. Males that began breeding early produced more offspring than those breeding later due to increases in both survival and number of litters produced. Heavy females produced more offspring than light females primarily due to their greater longevity (survival). Across individuals with only one mate during their lifetime, significant phenotypic selection was observed only on timing of first reproduction in both males and females. Monogamy in P. californicus due to increased reproductive success in males and females that invest in their pair bond rather than securing additional matings. -from Author

dc:title: Density-dependent changes in the spacing behaviour of female kin in red deer
dc:creator: Albon S.
dc:description: Female Cervus elaphus on the Island of Rhum (Scotland) aggregate in unstable matrilineal groups. The degree of spatial association (proximity) between individuals increases with their degree of relatedness as well as with their dominance rank but declines with increasing age. As population density doubled over 1974-1983, the degree of spatial association between female kin declined. At all ages, individuals spend less time close to their relatives and more with unrelated animals when population density was high. Thus, in mammals with fission/fusion societies like red deer, dispersal is a gradual process and it does not necessarily involve the total abandonment of the natal area by individuals as they disperse. -from Authors

dc:title: Low fecundity insular blue tits do not survive better as adults than high fecundity mainland ones
dc:creator: Blondel J.
dc:description: Prediction of higher adult survival rates of Parus caeruleus on Corsica, where clutch size is 27% lower than in a habitat on the mainland, has been tested from capture-recapture studies using models which include both survival and recapture probabilities. Average adult survival rates for both sexes combined were similar on the mainland and the island. Females survived slightly better on the island while males survived better on the mainland. Results do not support the assumption of a negative correlation between fecundity and adult survival and run counter to the dogma of higher survival rates of birds on islands. They are discussed in the light of the specific constraints of each environment, especially food resources. Other components than clutch size, especially post-fledging survival and age at first breeding must be involved in the trade-offs between fecundity and adult survival. (See also 92L/08158). -from Authors

dc:title: Aphids or their parasitoids: who actually benefits from ant- attendance?
dc:creator: Volkl W.
dc:description: The influence of ant-attendance on patterns of parasitism was studied for two parasitoid species attacking black bean aphid Aphis fabae, Trioxys angelicae, and Lysiphlebus cardui on the host-plants Euonymus europaeus and Cirsium arvense. Foraging T. angelicae females were heavily attacked by honeydew-collecting ants, but ants did not treat L. cardui females in an aggressive way. Ant-attendance provided a considerable protection for A. fabae against T. angelicae, but did not prevent a high parasitization success of L. cardui. Trioxys angelicae, which was restricted to unattended aphids, suffered from a high rate of hyperparasitization. In contrast, ant-attendance of parasitized aphids reduced the hyperparasitization of L. cardui significantly. The increased honeydew-production of parasitized A. fabae led to an increase in the number of honeydew-collecting ants and additionally intensified the protection of the preimaginal stages of L. cardui. Ant-attendance provided an "enemy-free space' for the primary parasitoid L. cardui against its hyperparasitoids, a new aspect in parasitoid reproductive strategies. -Author

dc:title: Fluctuating food abundance determines the lifetime reproductive success of male Tengmalm's owls
dc:creator: Korpimaki E.
dc:description: Examined the lifetime reproductive success (LRS) of male Aegolius funereus in W Finland where vole abundance fluctuates cyclically among years. Males were site-tenacious after their first breeding attempt. The productivity of 141 males, all of which started to breed during 1979-87, was studied up to 1990. They spent 1-7 yr (mean 1.5 yr) as breeders and raised 0-26 fledglings (mean 5.4) during their lifetime. The lifetime number of fledglings produced by males was highly significantly correlated with their lifetime contribution of known recruits to the breeding population. Most male fledglings (78%) died before the first breeding attempt. Of the young fledged in one year, 5% produced 50% of fledglings in the next generation, and 21% of males reared 50% of all fledglings produced by the population. Offspring survival from egg to fledgling was the most important component of LRS, followed by the life span and clutch size. Age of first breeding did not affect LRS, but polygynous males produced twice as many fledglings as monogamous ones. Among environmental factors, vole abundance was the most important determinant of LRS: males entering the breeding population in the low and increase phases of the vole cycle gained larger LRS than males recruiting in the peak and decrease phases. As the breeding life span of polygynous males was longer than that of monogamous ones and as there was no negative relationship between the brood size and the duration of breeding life, no evidence of reproductive costs could be obtained. Superior males may easily compensate for the large parental investment by increasing their food intake without risking their future survival. -Author

dc:title: Predation of waders (Charadrii) on prey populations: an exclosure experiment
dc:creator: Szekely T.
dc:description: In a mudflat in the Hortobagy National Park, Hungary, the most common invertebrates in the mud were chironomid larvae, which accounted for 90.5% of all invertebrates. Chironomid larval density in the exclosures averaging 11 075 individuals m-2. Ten species of waders, black-headed gulls Larus ridibundus and mallards Anas platyrhynchos either fed or roosted in the study sites. The most numerous were black-tailed godwits Limosa limosa, spotted redshanks Tringa erythropus and ruffs Philomachus pugnax, which comprised 39.5%, 33.6%, 25.1% of the total counted, respectively. At the end of the 13-day experiment, the invertebrate density was significantly lower in the control sites (1594 ind.m-2) compared with exclosures (11 938 ind.m-2). Thus birds removed 86.6% of the prey stocks. Prey biomass was also significantly lower in the control (1.3gm-2) than in the exclosures (9.5gm-2), but mean length of the chironomid larvae was not significantly different between control (7.87 mm) and exclosures (9.95mm). The number of prey estimated by observation to be taken daily by black-tailed godwit was 5765 prey m-2 for 13 days of the experiment while the estimates for spotted redshank and ruff were 1258 and 575 prey m-2, respectively. The total removed by black-tailed godwits, spotted redshanks and ruffs was therefore 7598 prey m-2. This compared with the 10 344 ind.m-2 estimated to be removed by birds in the exclosrue sites. The difference between the two methods is probably due to predation by other birds and to the high variances of both estimates. More small snails (Gyraulus sp.) were found in the control sites than in the exclosures, possibly because they were avoided by waders. -from Authors

dc:title: The western black-and-white colobus as a low-energy strategist: activity budgets, energy expenditure and energy intake
dc:creator: Dasilva G.
dc:description: As studied in SW Sierra Leone annual diet and activity budgets Colobus polykomos change seasonally: unripe tree seeds are the preferred food type, with increased time spent feeding during the peak of seed production. Time spent resting is highest during wet seasons, when seeds are not available and only leaves are eaten. The high energetic value of seeds compared to fruit flesh, young and mature leaves, is demonstrated. A diet of 100% seeds supplies sufficient calories for all estimates of energy intake and expenditure, whereas a diet of 100% leaves is unable to meet daily energy expenditure and only the highest estimates of feeding rate approach average daily metabolic needs. The advantages of detoxification, and the limitations of energy production for small-bodied fore-gut fermenters are outlined. Evidence that C. polykomos is hypometabolic is considered. The adaptations they show to periodic shortages of high energy foods are behavioural rather than physiological. -from Author

dc:title: Size, abundance, and energy use in communities
dc:creator: Griffiths D.
dc:description: The relation between abundance and body size has been modelled as a power function: some authors have reported exponents of -0.75 while others have reported values not significantly different from 0. The former value implies that populations use equivalent amounts of energy regardless of their size, while the latter implies energetic dominance by large species. Much of the disagreement results from the use of inappropriate methods to estimate the exponent. Data are re-analysed using structural regression and reduced major axis (RMA) methods. Most RMA estimates of the exponent are close to -1, consistent with greater energy consumption by small organisms than large in communities. -Author

dc:title: Habitat use by insular populations of Mus and Peromyscus: what is the role of competition?
dc:creator: Scott D.
dc:description: Examined interspecific competition between house mouse Mus musculus and white-footed mouse Peromyscus leucopus on a large Virginia barrier island. The species exhibited conspicuous differences in pre-removal habitat use, with Mus occupying grassland and Peromyscus occupying adjacent shrub thickets. Neither species exhibited a significant habitat shift or numerical increase following removal of its putative competitor. The absence of habitat shifts, which should be detectable even on the level of the individual, argue for the absence rather than non-detection of competition. The fact that Mus and Peromyscus could have coexisted at this location for only c300 yr argues against the reduction of competition by "competitive coevolution'. Results thus suggest that habitat selection and intraspecific interactions are much more important determinants of habitat use by these species than are interspecific interactions. -from Authors

dc:title: Regulation and stability of a free-living host-parasite system: Trichostrongylus tenuis in red grouse. II. Population models
dc:creator: Dobson A.
dc:description: The population dynamics of Lagopus lagopus scoticus and the parasitic nematode Trichostrongylus tenuis were explored to determine whether interactions between the parasite and host were sufficient to generate cycles in grouse abundance. Providing that the life expectancy of the free-living larvae is more than 2-4 wk, the parasite can readily establish in grouse populations. Larval arrestment tends to reduce the intrinsic growth rate of the parasite and thus increases the size of the host population required for the parasite to establish. Grouse numbers will tend to cycle when the parasites exhibit low degrees of aggregation and parasite-induced reductions in host fecundity are greater than parasite-induced increases in host mortality. The population cycles produced in the model have the slow increase followed by a rapid decline characteristic of the grouse population studied at Gunnerside, Yorkshire. The period of the cycles is determined by the intrinsic growth rate of the grouse population and either larval life expectancy (Model I), or the duration of larval arrestment (Model II) . Cycle periods decrease as host population growth rate increases, and lengthen with increases in either free-living larval life expectancy, or duration of larval arrestment. If duration of larval arrestment is sufficiently long (>6 months), the cycles die out and the dynamics of the grouse-nematode system are very stable. Numerical analysis of the model's behaviour suggest that a model with limited arrested larval stages more closely corresponds to the grouse populatins in N England. The 4-5 yr cycles exhibited by these populations will be more sporadic, or absent on estates where the parasite is unable to establish. The empirical data collected on T. tenuis are consistent with it being the cause of the cycles observed in grouse populations in N England. -from Authors

dc:title: Variation in the life span and size of the freshwater pearl mussel
dc:creator: Bauer G.
dc:description: Within the distribution area of Margaritifera margaritifera the maximum observed life span attained in a population varies from 30-132 yr and the maximum shell length from 80-145 mm. For both life-history traits, the growth constant k is a major determinant. This constant describes the shape of the average individual growth curve: the lower its value, the slower is the asymptote approached. Maximum size and life span increase as the growth constant declines and the maximum age almost equals the time necessary to complete the growth pattern. With increasing latitude, from Spain to the polar circle, k declines, whereas age and size increase, attributed to the close relationship between k and metabolism. As temperature decreases, metabolic rate declines and rate of growth decreases; the asymptote is approached slowly and this leads to a long life. Simultaneously, there is probably a shift in the anabolic-catabolic-balance increasing the asymptotic size and hence the maximum size. The growth constant and maximum life span also respond to the productivity of the habitat. There is a negative correlation between k and eutrophication, and the maximum life span is reduced as the concentration of nitrate increases. It is concluded that this variability is a case of phenotypic plasticity with no adaptive value because: 1) plasticity must be attributed to unavoidable physiological responses; 2) between populations the relationships between maximum life span, maximum size and reproductive output are positive, whereas trade-offs would be expected if variation in life-history tactics was the source of plasticity; and 3) the demographic consequences of plasticity may be highly disadvantageous. -from Author

dc:title: Do great tits adjust hatching spread, egg size and offspring sex ratio to changes in clutch size?
dc:creator: Slagsvold T.
dc:description: Many hole-nesting birds lay smaller clutches in small than in large nestboxes. Breeding success may be limited by cavity space in small boxes, but by food availability in large boxes. If so, birds nesting in small boxes may adopt a "brood survival strategy' (synchronous hatching and large final eggs), whereas those nesting in large boxes may adopt a "brood reduction strategy' (asynchronous hatching and small final eggs). The author studied initial and repeat nestings of Parus major in nestboxes with small (70cm2) and large (180cm2) basal areas, in two study plots. A clutch size adjustment to nestbox size was verified, with a difference between small and large boxes of 1-2 eggs, but contrary to expectation, no significant differences were found in either hatching spread, or in the relative size of the final egg laid. Alternative explanations for variation in hatching spread and egg size are discussed. Limitation, by energetic constraints, on the start of incubation and on egg formation may be of great importance. From assumptions made about the costs of rearing male and female offspring, and about the fitness distribution of the young in relation to their body weight, the authors expected that the sex ratio found for hatchlings would be higher in favour of males in small than in large nestboxes. An insignificant tendency in this direction was found. -from Authors

dc:title: African fig wasp communities: undersaturation and latitudinal gradients in species richness
dc:creator: Hawkins B.
dc:description: Examined species richenss patterns for the wasps associated with southern and central African Ficus to determine if fig wasp communities are saturated with species and if the degree of saturation (or undersaturation) differs in temperate and tropical communities. Saturation was tested by regressing local wasp-community richness (alpha diversity) against the regional wasp species richness (gamma diversity) of each fig species, and latitudinal variation in saturation was tested by regressing local community species richness against latitude. There was no evidence that either galler or parasitoid communities are saturated with species, a conclusion supported by high levels of variability in species richness found in individual trees and fruits and by generally low levels of resource utilisation by gallers. Local galler assemblage species richness was similar across a latitudinal gradient extending from 6°N to 34°S, suggesting that tropical and temperate communities are equally unsaturated. Local parasitoid community richness, however, dropped slightly towards the tropics, suggesting that tropical fig wasp parasitoid communities are even more unsaturated than temperate ones. The lack of saturation in fig wasp communities is judged to be largely due to a combination of strong phylogenetic constraints on wasp species, some of which have probably co-speciated with their hosts (which limits regional species richness) and the ability of wasps to colonize ephemeral and unpredictable host resources (which limits local species richness). The patterns are those expected for communities of specialists. -from Authors

dc:title: Genotype-environment interactions and relative clonal fitness in a marine bryozoan
dc:creator: Hughes D.J.
dc:description: Clones of Celleporella hyalina were propagated to give cohorts of genetically identical colonies which were reared in the field under three different water flow treatments, and over two seasonal periods. Total number of zooids per colony and number of gonozooids alone were both used as indices of clonal performance. By both zooid scores, clones varied greatly in mean performance, and thus in fitness. Correlations between fitness ranking in different environments were mostly positive, but many clones did show large shifts in rank order between environments. In autumn-winter some clones were of consistently high or low fitness in all three flow treatments, despite large treatment differences in mean zooid productivity. Seasonal differences had a greater effect on fitness ranking than flow regime, a pattern more pronounced when gonozooid number was used as the index of performance. Disparities in clonal performance were reduced in the least productive environments. These conditions caused a greater reduction in performance in genotypes of high average fitness. In spring-summer, replicate colonies often differed considerably in growth rate, even when growing closely adjacent to each other. -from Author

dc:title: Age-related reproductive success in the barnacle goose
dc:creator: Forslund P.
dc:description: A recently established breeding colony Branta leucopsis was studied on Gotland, Sweden. Reproductive success increased up to an age of 4-5 yr. Thus, clutch size, number of hatched young and number of fledged young increased, and hatching date was advanced with increasing age. This was due to the fact that individuals increased in reproductive success as they grew older. A possibly higher probability of survival among individuals that perform well in reproduction could not explain the higher reproductive success in older age-classes as compared to young age-classes of geese, because there were no associations between survival and reproductive success, and very few individuals did actually disappear between any two breeding seasons. Path analysis suggested age effects only at earlier stages of reproduction, ie timing of breeding and clutch size. These characters, in turn, were associated with number of fledged young. These findings were further supported by measurements of hatching success and rearing success, which did not seem to increase with age. Increased breeding experience was associated with early hatching date and larger clutch size in males, and with larger clutch size in females. -from Authors

dc:title: Dynamics of metapopulations: habitat destruction and competitive coexistence
dc:creator: Nee S.
dc:description: Takes a previously studied model for two species (one of which is competitively inferior) coexisting in a patchy environment, and examines the effects of removing patches (ie decreasing amount of available habitat). Habitat destruction or patch removal reduces the number (and proportion) or patches occupied by the superior competitor, but can result in an increase in the total number of patches occupied by the inferior competitor, even though there are fewer patches in total. Disturbance and destruction of habitat can create edge effects and other ecological changes favouring "weedy' species. Patch removal can by itself favour such species, even in the absence of other, concomitant changes. Thus habitat loss can bring about changes in community composition in remaining patches, even if such patches themselves undergo no intrinsic changes whatsoever. -from Authors

dc:title: Deterministic stability analysis can predict the dynamics of some stochastic population models
dc:creator: Taylor A.
dc:description: Some workers have suggested that the conclusions from standard deterministic population dynamics models do not hold for stochastic versions of the same models. Stochastic versions of two standard models - Hassell's (1975) single-species model and May's (1978) host-parasitoid model - were simulated, for a range of parameter values giving different deterministic dynamics. In several cases there was a qualitative difference in stochastic dynamics between systems which were deterministically stable and unstable: for the host-parasitoid model and the single-species model with weak regulation, the variability in densities was much greater for unstable systems than stable ones. In all cases, the stability eigenvalue λ obtained from deterministic analysis was clearly related to the variability of the stochastic simulations: populations varied less when /λ/ was small. Increasing the magnitude of the external stochastic variability produced greater variability in densities. -Author

dc:title: Adaptive superparasitism and patch time allocation in solitary parasitoids: an ESS model
dc:creator: Visser M.
